--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> One other thought, if you avoid specific points/areas then you may
still 
> end up with a bunch of genomes around the edge of these points/areas if 
> they were previously on a climb to a peak, because you still have the 
> peak in the fitness space but you prevent genomes from approaching it. 
> It's like a ring fence around the peak and as such is not necessarily 
> much better than just the peak - unless you perhaps gradually increase 
> the areas of the ring fence, by e.g. increasing the compatibility 
> threshold with the dead species that define the areas.

Seems this kind of situation is similar to organisms poisoning a
habitat with their waste products.  The longer a species "inhabits" an
area of the search space, the more poisoned it becomes. (With a decay
factor, of course.)  Poinsoned areas could decrease inhabitants
fitness, motivating them to leave.  Agents with a high enough fitness
would not be affected.  

Similar effects could be attained by genes each consuming a resource
of some sort.  Members of a species would consume a similar set of
resources.  If you limit the resources, you limit the size of a
species' population, and how many agents can search an area of the
space.  This is also another way for species to compete and cooperate
in complex ways, especially if agents are able to produce resources.
(Possibly linked to their fitness evaluation.)

GreG
